Permits and Licenses Student-Driver\'s Permit (SP) An authority granted by the LTO to a person who desires to learn to operate a motor vehicle. The student-driver must be accompanied by a duly licensed driver, acting as driving instructor, possessing the appropriate license code/s for the desired type of motor vehicle. Validity of Student-Driver\’s Permit Validity Period The SP is valid for 1 year from the date of issuance. After 1 year, it cannot be used for the practical driving course but can be used to apply for a Non-Professional Driver’s License (NPDL) if the course was completed within the validity period. After 2 Years The holder must acquire a new SP with the same SP number and restart the apprenticeship period from the new issuance date. All previous training records are retained. Renewal The SP can be renewed on or before the expiry date if the holder is not ready to apply for a Driver’s License (DL). Renewal after expiry requires only the basic fee, except for penalties due to traffic violations.
Conductor\’s License (CL) An authority granted by the LTO to a qualified person to assist the driver of a public utility vehicle in fare collection and/or ensuring the safety of the passengers and/or cargo while the said vehicle is in operation. Validity Of Conductor’s License (CL) A new CL is valid for 5 years from the licensee’s date of birth, unless revoked or suspended. Renewal for Compliant Holders If the holder commits no violations during the 5-year period, the CL can be renewed for 10 years. Late Renewal If renewed after 2 years from the expiry date, the holder must pass a written examination and pay the basic fee and an additional penalty.
Driver\’s License (DL) An authority in the form prescribed by the LTO granted to a person to operate motor vehicle that is either nonprofessional or professional driver’s license. Non-professional DL (NPDL) An authority in the form prescribed by the LTO granted to a person to operate a private motor vehicle. Professional DL (PDL) An authority in the form prescribed by the LTO granted to any driver hired or paid for driving or operating a motor vehicle whether for private use or for hire to the public. Driver\’s License Code (DL Code) Refers to the collective code representing the vehicle category/ies that a licensed person is allowed to operate. Driving Enhancement Program (DEP) An updated road safety seminar designed by LTO for DL holders. Drivers are required to attend this seminar prior to renewal of the initial five (5) year license. Vehicle Category (VC) Refers to motor vehicle category as specified in the Philippine National Standard on Road Vehicles-Classification and Definition. Restriction Code (RC) Refers to previous code representing the vehicle category/ies that a licensed person is allowed to operate.
Restriction Code and its Equivalent to Driver\’s License Code Notes: Holders of DL with MT Clutch Code are allowed to operate vehicles with Automatic Transmission (AT). Holders of DL with AT Clutch Code are not allowed to operate vehicles with Manual Transmission (MT). For new DL, applicants are only allowed to apply for NPDL under DL Codes A, A1, B, B1 and B2, or combination thereof.
Qualifications and Documentary Requirements Medical Conditions and Driving Indications Medical Certificate A certification issued by a registered physician of an LTO accredited medical clinic stating the result of applicant’s medical examination and valid for a period of sixty (60) days from the date of issuance. Drivers with driving conditions “2” or “3” or “4” or “5” are not allowed to operate For-Hire/ Public Utility Vehicles or Commercial Vehicles, unless, expressly allowed, in writing, by a qualified medical specialist.
Student-Driver\'s Permit New Driver\'s License A new DL is valid for five (5) years reckoned from the date of birth of the licensee, unless sooner revoked or suspended. A DL holder who has not committed any violation/s during the five (5) year period preceding its expiration is entitled to a renewal of such license valid for ten (10) years. Renewal of Driver\'s License Late Renewal (After 2 Years) Requires the holder to: Pass theoretical and practical examination, Pay the basic fee and an additional penalty.
General Procedures
Regulatory Signs
1. Priority Signs Signs that inform road users of traffic laws and regulations which, if disregarded, will constitute an offense. Stop Sign Driver must stop at designated STOP LINE. No parking within 6 meters. Give way Sign Yield to the vehicles on right side of intersection. Left Turner Must Give Way When turning left at intersections, you can only have the right of way if you use your turn signal at least 30 meters before reaching the intersection. If there are cars arriving or already too close to the intersection, yield and make them pass.
2. Directional Signs These signs indicate the direction in which the motorist is obliged to follow. Vehicle May Pass Either Side
3. Restrictive Signs No entry for all types of vehicle No entry for specific types of vehicle No Pedestrian Crossing Pedestrian are not allowed to cross the road. Using Overpass or Use Ped Xing Pedestrian must use an overpass or pedestrian crossing. No Right Turn or No Left Turn Vehicles are not allowed to turn left or right. No U-Turn Vehicles are not allowed to make a U-turn. No Overtaking Zone
4. Speed Signs Maximum Speed Restriction End of Speed Restrictions Minimum Speed Restriction
5. Parking and Stopping Signs Allowable parking and loading zone at a given time and place. No stopping anytime. No loading and unloading zone. No parking on fire hydrant within 4 meters. No waiting. Bus-PUJ Stop Zone. Parking is not allowed. Bus Stop Zone. PUJ Stop Zone. No Parking: Tow-Away Zone. Parked vehicle will be towed. No Stopping or Parking anytime within the yellow box. No Parking anytime from Monday to Friday. Right Turner Cross at Broken Lines. Vehicles from the left lane may cross the broken line to turn right within the BUS/PUJ zone.
Warning Signs 1. Horizontal Signs These signs are used to indicate the type of road curve ahead of the motorist 2. Intersection Signs Signs installed before intersection or junctions 3. Advance Warning Signs Used to indicate signalized intersection and to warn the presence of STOP and GIVE WAY signs Traffic Light Ahead Driver must not park or stop within six (6) meters of this sign as it reduces visibility for other drivers 4. Road Width Signs 5. Road Obstacles Signs 6. Pedestrian Signs Pedestrian crossing ahead Be aware of and stop for children crossing ahead Persons with Disabilities (PWDs) crossing ahead Advising the pedestrians to cross at designated areas Be aware and slowdown on bicycle lane ahead 7. Railway Level Crossing Signs Railroad Crossing Railway Crossing Warning Alternative railway crossing is positioned in an area that can be easily seen 8. Supplementary Signs
Guide/Informative Signs 1. Advance Direction Signs These signs indicate the direction(s) in which the motorists are given information or direction 2. Intersection Direction Signs Visible in less than 1 kilometer before an intersection 3. Reassurance Direction Signs Approximate distance of a particular exit
Signs on Expressway These signs are essential for the driver to have an advanced information to ensure that they can position their vehicles in the correct lanes 1. Expressway Approach Signs Installed in advance or at the nearest intersection or interchange leading to the expressway 2. Expressway Information Signs Prohibited on Expressway Prohibits traveling on an expressway Lane Direction Used to guide the motorists into correct lanes leading to an interchange Toll Charges Inform motorists the amount of toll charges required to pay at the toll plaza Advance Exit Signs Placed in advance of an exit
Pavement Markings Longitudinal Lines 1. Center or Separation Line Crossing of solid white lines requires special care and is discouraged. 2. Lane Line Changing of lane is allowed provided that it is safe and will not result to obstruction. 3. Barrier Line a. Double Solid Lines No Overtaking and No Crossing. b. Single Solid Yellow Line Crossing is allowed but no overtaking c. Single Yellow Line with Broken White Line No overtaking but crossing is allowed on the side of the solid yellow line. Overtaking and crossing is allowed on the side of the broken white line. d. Broken Yellow Line Crossing and overtaking is allowed with necessary precaution. e. Broken and Solid Yellow Line Crossing and overtaking is allowed on the side of the broken line with caution but overtaking is not allowed on the side of the solid line. 4. Edge Line Used to separate the outside edge of the road from the shoulder. 5. Continuity Line Continuity line on the left side means the lane is ending or exiting and that the driver must change lanes if the driver wants to continue in the current direction. Continuity lines on the right means that the lane will continue unaffected.
Traversal Lines Stop Line Vehicles are required to stop before the white line Give Way Line Markings consisting of two adjacent broken white lines across the carriageway at which drivers must give way to all traffic in accordance with the standard sign. Pedestrian Intersection Roundabout Holding Lines Vehicles within the rotunda have the right-of-way over vehicles which are just about to enter
Other Lines Turn Line Used to guide vehicles through a turning movement at intersections Parking Bay Used to designate parking space, but take note of PWD Parking Mark

Traffic Violations and Penalties
Driving Without a Valid License Operating a vehicle without a valid driver\'s license. Penalty: Php 3,000 fine.
Reckless Driving 1st Offense: Php 2,000 fine. 2nd Offense: Php 3,000 fine and suspension of driver\'s license for three months. 3rd Offense: Php 10,000 fine and suspension of driver\'s license for six months. Subsequent Offenses: Php 10,000 fine and revocation of driver\'s license.
Driving Under the Influence (DUI) Non-Professional Drivers: - 1st Conviction: Confiscation and suspension of driver\'s license for 12 months. - 2nd Conviction: Revocation of driver\'s license. Professional Drivers: - 1st Conviction: Confiscation and perpetual revocation of driver\'s license.
Failure to Wear Seatbelt 1st Offense: Php 1,000 fine. 2nd Offense: Php 2,000 fine. 3rd and Subsequent Offenses: Php 5,000 fine and suspension of driver\'s license for one week.
Failure to Wear Standard Protective Motorcycle Helmet 1st Offense: Php 1,500 fine. 2nd Offense: Php 3,000 fine. 3rd Offense: Php 5,000 fine. Subsequent Offenses: Php 10,000 fine.
Illegal Parking Parking in prohibited areas such as intersections, within 5 meters of intersections, in front of driveways, etc. Penalty: Php 1,000 fine.
Disregarding Traffic Signs Ignoring or disobeying traffic signs. Penalty: Php 1,000 fine.
Driving an Unregistered Motor Vehicle Operating a vehicle that is not registered with the LTO. Penalty: Php 10,000 fine and impoundment of the vehicle until properly registered.
Unauthorized Modification of Motor Vehicle Modifying a vehicle without approval from the LTO. Penalty: Php 5,000 fine.
